definition[0]: to move earth, snow etc, or to make a hole in the ground, using a spade or your hands
example[0]: They dig a small hole in the sand to bury their eggs.
definition[1]: to remove something, especially vegetables, from the ground using a spade
definition[2]: to put your hand into something, especially in order to search for something
example[4]: She dug around in her bag for a pen.
example[5]: He dug his hands deep into his pockets.
definition[4]: to make a hole in the ground using your hands, a tool, or a machine
example[7]: Some workmen were digging a trench at the side of the road.
example[8]: In Africa, the people know where to dig for water.
definition[5]: to dig a hole in the ground, using your hands or a tool
example[9]: Make a hole just big enough for the plant’s roots.
definition[6]: if an animal burrows, it makes a hole or a passage in the ground by digging the earth with its feet, nose etc
example[10]: The rabbits had burrowed a hole under the fence.
definition[7]: to turn over the soil using a machine or a tool pulled by animals, to prepare the soil for planting seeds
example[11]: The farmers here still plough their fields using buffaloes.
definition[8]: to dig a large hole in the ground, especially as a preparation for building something
example[12]: The men began excavating the hole for the pool.
definition[9]: to make a deep round hole in the ground using a special machine, especially in order to look for oil or water
example[13]: Companies need a special licence to bore for oil.
definition[10]: a joke or remark that you make to annoy or criticize someone
example[14]: He couldn’t resist a dig at the referee.
example[15]: Here was a chance to have a dig at trade unionists.
definition[11]: an organized process of digging in order to find ancient objects for study
